Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in biology and require a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science and engineering. The fellowships advance NSF efforts to diversify the STEM workforce now and in the future. This fellowship to Maria Vasquez supports a research and training plan at Cal Poly San Luis Obispo in the laboratory of Lars Tomanek and includes a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science. The research examines how heat and hyposalinity stresses affect both native and invasive species of mussels in field and laboratory experiments. The research introduces the Fellow to molecular genetic and proteomics techniques and provides research mentoring to undergraduate students, including those from groups under-represented in STEM fields.

Intertidal marine organisms inhabit a stressful environment with multiple environmental stressors that can perturb physiological tolerances thereby shifting species ranges of both native an invasive species. This research utilizes proteomics, a method to observe global protein abundance, to understand tolerance limits and potential environmenatl impacts on two intertidal mussel species by testing responses to multiple environmental stressors. In addition, the potential role of sirtuins (involved in post-translational modifications) as a mechanism in the stress response of marine intertidal invertebrates is being investigated. The research integrates both complex methodologies and experimental designs to better simulate the multiple stressor environment inhabited by marine intertidal species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding physiological tolerances of marine organisms to environmental stress is key to predicting species adaptability under climate change. Daily tidal fluctuations expose marine intertidal organisms to environmental stressors such that at low tide seawater is not present and therefore respiration, elimination of waste products, and feeding are limited. In addition, low tide aerial exposure may include exposure to increased heat stress, hypoxia, desiccation and predation. In contrast, exposure at high tide allows for physiological processes to continue due to the presence of seawater. We can use marine organisms exposed to stressful environmental conditions to understand stress tolerance and adaptability to changing environmental conditions, with particular interest in understanding future effects of global climate change. In addition, by integrating a multi-stressor exposure methodology in combination with chemical inhibition of key stress response proteins (i.e., sirtuins), we can experimentally investigate the role environmental stress plays in influencing marine organismal stress tolerance.

For my research the species of interest were the intertidal mussel congeners of the genus Mytilus that vary in their physiological tolerances to stress. Along the Pacific coast the invasive M. galloprovincialis can withstand elevated heat exposure, but it is vulnerable to hyposalinity while the native M. trossulus is more tolerant to hyposaline conditions but vulnerable to heat stress. Additional differences in stress tolerance also exhist when exposed to acute heat shock and emersion induced hypoxia during low tide. Recent findings suggest that sirtuins, a group of NAD+ dependent deacetylases, influence the environmental stressor tolerances in these two mussel species and regulate the cellular stress response (CSR) differently between the two mussel species. Using proteomics, I sought to understand the role of sirtuins in regulating the cellular stress response (CSR) in Mytilid mussels exposed to environmental stressors (hypoxia, aerial heat, and hyposalinity). 

My postdoctoral fellowship also sought to develop my skills as a scientist, mentor, future faculty member. My postdoctoral award allowed me to train and learn 2D gel electrophoresis and Mass Analyzer Laser Desorption Ionization tandem time of flight mass spectrometry. I also supervised and mentored over 30 undergraduates, 10 master’s students, and 10 underrepresented minorities. I served as an ambassador for underrepresented students working with the Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation and the Bridges to the Baccalaureate programs at my host institution to recruit underrepresented students into scientific research. I published one first author peer reviewed paper with three additional papers in review, I secured funding from the CSU COAST grant development program for research to follow the termination of my NSF postdoctoral award ($16,000), and I applied to tenure track faculty jobs and was offered an assistant professor position at Southern Oregon University.

During my fellowship I I first completed a project investigating the effect of sirtuins as regulators of the cellular stress reponse in Mytilid mussels in response to acute heat stress. A comparison of the proteomic responses of M. galloprovincialis and M. trossulus to an acute heat shock in the presence and absence of the sirtuin inhibitor suramin (which inhibits SIRT1, 2 and 5), showed that sirtuins affected molecular chaperones, oxidative stress proteins, metabolic enzymes, cytoskeletal and signaling proteins more in the heat-sensitive M. trossulus than in the heat-tolerant M. galloprovincialis. Interactions between sirtuin inhibition and changes in the abundance of proteins of b-oxidation and oxidative stress in M. trossulus, suggest a greater role of sirtuins in shifting metabolism to reduce the production of reactive oxygen species near thermal limits. Furthermore, RNA-binding proteins initiating and inhibiting translation were affected by suramin in M. galloprovincialis and in M. trossulus, respectively. Western blot analysis showed that the mitochondrial sirtuin 5 (SIRT5) was generally three times higher and increased with acute heat stress in response to sirtuin inhibition in M. trossulus but not in M. galloprovincialis, suggesting a possible feedback response in the former species and a greater reliance on SIRT5 for its stress response. Our findings suggest that SIRT5 plays an important role in setting interspecific differences in stress tolerance in Mytilus by affecting the stress proteome. This study was accepted for publication in the Journal of Experimental Biology. Second, I completed a novel study also using Mytilid mussels exposed to both aerial heat and hyposalinity using a custom built tidal simulator. The purpose of this study was to investigate the synergistic effects of multiple stressors on the mussel proteomic response. Interestingly, multi-stressor exposures showed antagonistic effects rather than synergistic effects, which would not have been predicted from single stressor exposures. For example, in M. galloprovincialis, the molecular chaperone sHSP24.1 showed increased protein abundance under aerial heat alone and hyposalinity alone, but the combination of stressors significantly decreased the protein abundance. This study reveals complex multi-stressor interactions highlighting the need to study stress tolerance under multiple stressor scenarios.
